item.title: Histograms
item.description:
library(Lahman)
library(sqldf)
library(ggplot2)

A histogram is a graphical representation, similar to a bar chart in structure, that organizes a group of data points into user-specified ranges. The histogram condenses a data series into an easily interpreted visual by taking many data points and grouping them into logical ranges or bins.

query<-"SELECT weight
FROM Master"

result<-sqldf(query)

ggplot()+
  geom_histogram(data=result,aes(x=weight),color="green",fill="white",bins=50)+
  ggtitle("Body Weight Distribution for Baseball Players")
## Warning: Removed 854 rows containing non-finite values (stat_bin).

Weight distribtution for baseball players

item.title: Scatter Plots
item.description:
library(Lahman)
library(sqldf)
library(ggplot2)
#Extractcing Data----------------------------

query<-"SELECT playerID,sum(HR) AS career_HR ,sum(SO) AS career_SO 
FROM Batting
GROUP BY playerID
HAVING sum(HR)>=400"

result<-sqldf(query)

#Visulaizing Data----------------------------

ggplot()+
  geom_point(data=result,aes(x=career_SO,y=career_HR), size=3, color="blue")+
  ggtitle("Career Strikeouts vs. Homeruns for Great Hitters")+
  xlab("Career Strikeouts")+
  ylab("Career Homerunes")

In the above chart, I created a scatter plot using career strikeouts as the x-axis and career homeurns as the y-axis. I changed the color and the size of the dots making them size 3 and color blue.

item.title: Time Series
item.description:
library(Lahman)
library(sqldf)
library(ggplot2)

Time Series graphs are related to scatter plots but the main difference is that time series shows a change over time or a trend.

# Extraction----------------------------

query<-"SELECT yearID,HR
FROM Batting
WHERE playerID='ruthba01'"

result<-sqldf(query)

# Visualization-------------------------

ggplot()+
  #geom_point(data=result,aes(x=yearID,y=HR))+
  geom_line(data=result,aes(x=yearID,y=HR))+
  ggtitle("Ruth's Homerun Totals Throughout the Years")+
  xlab("Year")+
  ylab("Homeruns")

The Graph above shows Babe Ruths Homerun total throughout his career.

item.title: Bar Plot
item.description:
library(Lahman)
library(sqldf)
library(ggplot2)
query<-"SELECT name,HR
FROM Teams
WHERE yearID=1980
ORDER BY HR"

result<-sqldf(query)

result$name<-factor(result$name,levels=result$name)

ggplot()+
  geom_bar(data=result,aes(x=name,y=HR),stat='identity',color="white",fill="blue")+
  coord_flip()+
  ylab("Homeruns")+
  xlab("Teams")+
  ggtitle("1980 Team Homerun Distribution")

The code above shows homerun totals of every team from the 1980â€™s. Usually the bar graph would not be horizontal but vertical. I used the coord_flip() command to make it horizontal.
